question: what are the conflicts between different regulatory bodies related to fire codes for egress
answer:
Below is what can be determined from the provided Washington State fire/building code materials. The documents you gave are **state-level** (IBC/IFC with Washington amendments); they do not include any Seattle Municipal Code (SMC) or Seattle Fire Code amendments, so I cannot show a true “State vs. City” conflict.  

However, there **are** internal priority rules and potential tensions between different *state-adopted* codes and referenced standards (IBC, IFC, NFPA 130, Energy Code). I’ll focus on those, since they are clearly documented.

---

## 1. Priority Between Different State‑Adopted Codes

The Washington State Building Code Council adopts multiple model codes (IBC, IFC, IMC, Energy Code, etc.). The state amendments explicitly state how conflicts between these codes are resolved.

### Key State Rule on Conflicts

The Washington amendment to the IBC states:

> “Where there is a conflict between codes, an earlier named code takes precedence over a later named code.”  
> [Source 6] (IBC International Building Code, p.3)

It then lists the adopted codes in order, including:

- International Building Code and amendments – WAC 51‑50  
- International Fire Code, Standards and amendments – WAC 51‑54A  
- Wildland‑Urban Interface Code – WAC 51‑55  
- Uniform Plumbing Code – WAC 51‑56  
[Source 6] (IBC International Building Code, p.3)

So, if an egress requirement in the IBC conflicts with one in the IFC, the **earlier‑named code in that list governs**. This is a built‑in conflict‑resolution rule between regulatory bodies (building vs. fire).

The same section also says:

> “Where, in any specific case, different sections of this Code specify different materials, methods of construction or other requirements, the most restrictive shall govern. Where there is conflict between a general requirement and a specific requirement, the specific requirement shall be applicable.”  
> [Source 6] (IBC International Building Code, p.3)

So within a single code (e.g., IBC), if two sections differ on egress, the **more restrictive** or **more specific** requirement controls.

**Implication for egress:**  
If, for example, the IFC commentary or a referenced standard suggested a longer allowable travel distance, but the IBC (earlier‑named) or a more specific IBC section imposed a shorter distance, the **shorter (more restrictive) distance** would govern.

---

## 2. IBC/IFC vs. NFPA 130 for Transit Stations (Egress Distances & Capacity)

For fixed transit and passenger rail stations, Washington adopts NFPA 130 but **modifies it** through the IFC/IBC. This creates potential friction between:

- NFPA 130’s original text, and  
- The Washington‑amended IFC/IBC provisions that override or modify it.

### 2.1 Means of Egress Must Follow IBC Chapter 10

The Washington amendment to NFPA 130 (via IFC Section 4901) states:

> “5.3.1.1 The provisions for means of egress for a station shall comply with the International Building Code, Chapter 10, except as herein modified.”  
> [Source 4] (IBC International Fire Code, p.198)

So, for stations, **IBC Chapter 10 is the baseline** for egress, and NFPA 130 is only used as modified.

### 2.2 Travel Distance Limits for Platforms

Washington modifies NFPA 130 Section 5.3.3.4:

> “5.3.3.4 Travel distance. For open stations the maximum travel distance on the platform to a point at which a means of egress route leaves the platform shall not exceed 100 m (325 ft.). For enclosed stations the travel distance to an exit shall not exceed 76 m (250 ft.).”  
> [Source 3] (IBC International Fire Code, p.199)

This is a **specific** egress travel‑distance rule for transit platforms, which may differ from:

- General IBC Chapter 10 travel‑distance limits for similar occupancies, and  
- The unmodified NFPA 130 values (not shown here, but clearly being replaced).

Because the amendment says “Modify NFPA 130 Section 5.3.3.4 as follows,” the **Washington‑amended values (100 m / 76 m)** control over the original NFPA 130 text.

### 2.3 Escalators and Egress Capacity

Washington also modifies NFPA 130 to limit how much egress capacity can be credited to escalators:

> “5.3.5.4 Escalators shall not account for more than one-half of the egress capacity at any one level.”  
> [Source 3] (IBC International Fire Code, p.199)

And it deletes another NFPA 130 provision:

> “4901.14 NFPA 130 Section 5.3.5. Delete NFPA 130 Section 5.3.5.5.”  
> [Source 3] (IBC International Fire Code, p.199)

So if the original NFPA 130 allowed more escalator capacity or had a different rule in 5.3.5.5, Washington’s adoption **overrides** that. Any conflict is resolved in favor of the **state‑amended IFC/IBC text**.

### 2.4 Doors, Gates, and Security Grilles – Egress Capacity

Washington modifies NFPA 130 Section 5.3.7:

> “5.3.7.1 The egress capacity for doors and gates in a means of egress serving public areas shall be computed as follows:  
> 1. Sixty people per minute (p/min) for single leaf doors and gates.  
> 2. 0.0819 p/mm‑min (2.08 p/in.‑min) for biparting multileaf doors and gates measured for the clear width dimension.”  
> [Source 3] (IBC International Fire Code, p.199)

And:

> “5.3.7.2.1 Security grilles are allowed when designed and operated in accordance with the International Building Code.”  
> [Source 2] (IBC International Fire Code, p.199)

So, if NFPA 130 originally had different flow rates or conditions for security grilles, those are **superseded** by these Washington‑specific values and the requirement to comply with the IBC.

---

## 3. IFC vs. IBC on Number of Exits and Common Path for Transit Stations

The Washington‑amended IFC and IBC coordinate on egress, but there are special exceptions for transit stations that could appear to conflict with general rules.

### 3.1 General Rule for Number of Exits (IBC/IFC 1006.2.1)

The Washington amendment to IBC/IFC Section 1006.2.1 states:

> “Two exits or exit access doorways from any space shall be provided where the design occupant load or the common path of egress travel distance exceeds the values listed in Table 1006.2.1.”  
> [Source 9] (IBC International Building Code, p.112); [Source 10] (IBC International Fire Code, p.121)

With exceptions for certain spaces (foyers, care suites, unoccupied mechanical rooms) [Source 9] (IBC International Building Code, p.112); [Source 10] (IBC International Fire Code, p.121).

### 3.2 Special Transit‑Station Exception in IFC

The IFC adds a specific exception for fixed transit and passenger rail stations:

> “4. The common path of travel for fixed transit and passenger rail system stations shall be in accordance with Section 4901.”  
> [Source 8] (IBC International Fire Code, p.121)

And:

> “1006.2.1.1 Three or more exits or exit access doorways. Three exits or exit access doorways shall be provided from any space with an occupant load of 501 to 1,000. Four exits or exit access doorways shall be provided from any space with an occupant load greater than 1,000.  
> EXCEPTION: The number of required exits for fixed transit and passenger rail systems may be reduced by one at open stations.”  
> [Source 8] (IBC International Fire Code, p.121)

So, for **open transit stations**:

- General rule: 3 exits for 501–1,000 occupants; 4 exits for >1,000.  
- Special rule: **may be reduced by one** for fixed transit/passenger rail systems at open stations.

This is a **specific exception** to the general egress rule. Under the IBC conflict‑resolution principle, the **specific requirement controls** over the general one [Source 6] (IBC International Building Code, p.3). So there is no unresolved conflict; the code itself tells you to apply the special transit‑station rule.

---

## 4. Energy Code vs. Mechanical Code (Not Egress, but Illustrative)

While not directly about egress, the state amendment gives another explicit example of how conflicts between regulatory bodies are resolved:

> “In the case of conflict between the duct insulation requirements of the International Mechanical Code and the duct insulation requirements of the Energy Code, the Energy Code, or where applicable, a local jurisdiction's energy code, shall govern.”  
> [Source 6] (IBC International Building Code, p.3)

This shows the same pattern: when two adopted codes conflict, the state specifies which one wins.

---

## Summary: Nature of “Conflicts” and How They’re Resolved

From the provided materials, the “conflicts” between regulatory bodies (building vs. fire vs. NFPA 130 vs. energy) are **anticipated and resolved in the text itself**:

1. **Between different state‑adopted codes (IBC vs. IFC, etc.)**  
   - Earlier‑named code in the adoption list takes precedence.  
   - Within a code, the more restrictive or more specific requirement governs.  
   [Source 6] (IBC International Building Code, p.3)

2. **Between IBC/IFC and NFPA 130 for transit stations**  
   - NFPA 130 is adopted but heavily modified.  
   - Means of egress must comply with IBC Chapter 10 “except as herein modified.”  
   - Specific travel distances, egress capacities, and use of escalators/doors/grilles are set by the Washington amendments, which override the original NFPA 130 text.  
   [Source 3] (IBC International Fire Code, p.199); [Source 4] (IBC International Fire Code, p.198); [Source 2] (IBC International Fire Code, p.199)

3. **Between general egress rules and special transit‑station rules**  
   - General exit‑number and common‑path rules in Section 1006.2.1 apply, **except** where special transit‑station exceptions in Section 4901 and 1006.2.1.1 apply.  
   - The code explicitly allows fewer exits for open transit stations and directs common path to Section 4901.  
   [Source 8] (IBC International Fire Code, p.121)

Because no Seattle‑specific amendments or SMC provisions were provided, I cannot identify or classify **State vs. City** conflicts on egress. If you want that level of analysis, the next step would be to supply or point to:

- The relevant Seattle Fire Code or SMC chapter on egress, and  
- Any Seattle‑specific amendments to IBC/IFC/NFPA 130,

and I can then build a friction matrix comparing those to the state‑level provisions above.

question: Court rulings interpreting 'vested rights' vs current SMC land use codes
answer:
Washington appellate courts and the Seattle Municipal Code (SMC) both address “vested rights,” but they do it in different ways and at different levels:

1. How Washington courts define and apply “vested rights”  

   Washington’s vested rights doctrine is a judge‑made rule (later partially codified) that protects a developer’s right to have a project reviewed under the land use regulations in effect at a specific “vesting” date.

   Key points from the cases:

   - Origin and purpose  
     - The doctrine “stems from the constitutional principle of fundamental fairness” and is described as “a constitutional protection for property rights.” [Source 5] (Arends v. State, p.5).  
     - Its purpose is “to provide a measure of certainty to developers and to protect their expectations against fluctuating land use policy.” [Source 7] (Arends v. State, p.2, quoting Noble Manor Co.).

   - Classic rule in land‑use context  
     - In land use, vested rights “entitle developers to have a land development proposal processed under the regulations in effect at the time a complete building permit application is filed, regardless of later changes in zoning or other land use regulations.” [Source 5] (Arends v. State, p.5, quoting Abbey Rd. Grp.).  
     - Earlier cases held that “An owner of property has a vested right to put it to a permissible use as provided for by prevailing zoning ordinances. The right accrues at the time an application for a building permit is made.” [Source 3] (Arends v. State, p.3, quoting State ex rel. Ogden v. City of Bellevue).

   - “Date certain” concept  
     - Washington uses a “date certain” standard: “Our state employs a ‘date certain’ standard for vesting.” [Source 3] (Arends v. State, p.3, quoting Town of Woodway v. Snohomish County).

   - Limits and evolution  
     - The Supreme Court notes that Washington’s vested rights doctrine “as originally judicially recognized applied to development rights in property interest” and has evolved over time. [Source 4] (Arends v. State, p.4).  
     - The court also acknowledges that “While it originated at common law, the vested rights doctrine is now statutory.” [Source 5] (Arends v. State, p.5, quoting Town of Woodway).  
     - There is concern that some cases have “stretched the doctrine of vested rights beyond its constitutional boundaries,” even though the particular Arends case was not one of them. [Source 6] (Arends v. State, p.14).

   - Interaction with the Growth Management Act (GMA)  
     - Under RCW 36.70A.302(3)(a), a “development permit application not vested under state or local law before receipt of the board’s order … vests to the local ordinance or resolution that is determined by the board not to substantially interfere with the fulfillment of the goals of this chapter.” [Source 16] (RCW 36.70A, p.85).  
     - This shows that state law explicitly ties vesting to “state or local law” and to the timing of applications relative to Growth Management Hearings Board orders.

2. How the Seattle Municipal Code defines vesting for land use permits  

   Seattle codifies its own vesting rules in SMC 23.76.026, which governs when Master Use Permit (MUP) components vest:

   - General vesting rule for MUP components (other than plats)  
     SMC 23.76.026.A provides that, except as otherwise stated or required by law, “applications for all Master Use Permit components other than subdivisions and short subdivisions shall be considered vested under the Land Use Code and other land use control ordinances in effect on the date” one of the following occurs [Source 12] (SMC Title 23, p.1465):

     1. “That notice of the Director’s decision on the application is published, if the decision is appealable to the Hearing Examiner;” [Source 12] (SMC Title 23, p.1465).  
     2. “Of the Director’s decision, if the decision is not appealable to the Hearing Examiner;” [Source 12] (SMC Title 23, p.1465).  
     3. “A valid and fully complete building permit application is filed, as determined under Section 106 of the Seattle Building Code or Section R105 of the Seattle Residential Code, if it is filed prior to the date established in subsections 23.76.026.A.1 or 23.76.026.A.2; or” [Source 12] (SMC Title 23, p.1465).

     In other words, for many MUP components, vesting can occur at:
     - publication of the Director’s decision (if appealable),  
     - the Director’s decision date (if not appealable), or  
     - an earlier complete building permit application date, if that comes first.

   - Optional application of newer code provisions  
     SMC 23.76.026.B allows applicants to opt into newer, more recent code provisions:

     - “Notwithstanding any other provision of this Section 23.76.026 or this Chapter 23.76, an applicant may elect, at such time and in such manner as the Director may permit, that specific Land Use Code provisions that became effective after the applicant’s application vested may nonetheless be applied to the application, pursuant to authorization for such election set forth elsewhere in this Title 23.” [Source 21] (SMC Title 23, p.1466).

     This codifies a one‑way flexibility: applicants can choose to be governed by newer, more recent standards, but they retain the right to the older standards as of their vesting date.

3. How the court doctrine and SMC approach relate (conceptually)

   Based on the retrieved materials:

   - Both the courts and SMC recognize vesting as a timing rule that fixes which regulations apply to a project:
     - Courts: vesting at the time of a complete building permit application, giving the right to be processed under regulations then in effect. [Source 5] (Arends v. State, p.5).  
     - SMC: vesting for MUP components at the time of decision/decision notice, or earlier at a complete building permit application, under the Land Use Code and “other land use control ordinances” then in effect. [Source 12] (SMC Title 23, p.1465).

   - State law (GMA) explicitly defers to “state or local law” for vesting and then ties vesting to the ordinance that the Growth Management Hearings Board finds consistent with GMA goals. [Source 16] (RCW 36.70A, p.85).

   - The Supreme Court acknowledges that the vested rights doctrine is now “statutory” in Washington [Source 5] (Arends v. State, p.5), which is consistent with local codifications like SMC 23.76.026.

4. If you want more detail

If you tell me what you’re trying to do (e.g., “I’m filing a MUP for a mixed‑use project in Seattle and want to know which code version applies”), I can:

- Walk through how the case law and SMC 23.76.026 would apply to that specific permit path, with citations; or  
- Focus on how vesting interacts with later code changes, appeals, or GMA challenges, again using the retrieved sources.

question: Does Seattle's noise ordinance conflict with construction hour limits?
answer:
Yes, there is a real tension between:

1. Seattle’s **Noise Ordinance** (SMC 25.08), which allows construction noise above standard exterior sound limits during certain hours, and  
2. Separate **construction‑hour limits** that can be imposed under the Land Use Code or project‑specific conditions.

Because you asked about “conflict,” I’ll walk through the specific provisions and then summarize the friction in a table.

---

### 1. What the Seattle Noise Ordinance allows for construction

SMC 25.08.425 explicitly allows construction and maintenance equipment to exceed the normal exterior sound level limits during specified hours:

- In many residential and neighborhood commercial zones:

  > “Within Lowrise, Midrise, Highrise, Residential‑Commercial, and Neighborhood Commercial zones, **between 7 a.m. and 7 p.m. on weekdays and between 9 a.m. and 7 p.m. on weekends and legal holidays**, except that for parking lot maintenance or if the equipment is being used for a public project, then **between 7 a.m. and 10 p.m. on weekdays and between the hours of 9 a.m. and 10 p.m. on weekends and legal holidays**.”  
  > [Source 1] (Title 25 - Environmental Protection and Historic Preservation, p.186)

- In all other zones:

  > “Within all other zones, **between 7 a.m. and 10 p.m. on weekdays and between 9 a.m. and 10 p.m. on weekends and legal holidays**.”  
  > [Source 2] (Title 25 - Environmental Protection and Historic Preservation, p.186)

During those windows, construction equipment may exceed the base exterior sound limits by up to 25 dB(A) for typical heavy equipment:

> “During the time periods specified in subsection 25.08.425.A, the exterior sound level limits… may be exceeded by no more than the following dB(A)'s for the following types of equipment: **Twenty‑five dB(A) for equipment on construction sites, including but not limited to crawlers, tractors, dozers…**”  
> [Source 2] (Title 25 - Environmental Protection and Historic Preservation, p.186)

The City’s own design standards summarize this as:

> “The City regulates noise through enforcement of its Noise Ordinance (SMC 25.08)… **This ordinance regulates maximum noise levels when construction occurs in the evening (daytime construction noise is exempt).** SPU’s operation, maintenance, and capital construction projects must comply with these provisions or otherwise obtain a variance from SDCI.”  
> [Source 5] (2DesignForPermittingEnvReviewFinalRedacted, p.12)

So, under SMC 25.08 alone, construction noise is effectively allowed (subject to the special limits) as early as 7 a.m. and as late as 10 p.m. in many zones.

---

### 2. Separate authority to limit hours of operation (including construction impacts)

The Land Use Code authorizes the City to restrict hours of operations for uses that create adverse impacts:

> “**The hours of operation for all processes creating any adverse impacts on residentially or commercially zoned land may be limited**;  
> Truck and service traffic associated with the heavy manufacturing use shall be directed away from streets serving lots in nonindustrial zones;”  
> [Source 11] (Title 23 - Land Use Code, p.666)

This is a separate regulatory tool from the Noise Ordinance. It allows SDCI, through land use approvals or conditions, to:

- Limit hours of “processes” that create adverse impacts (which can include noise), even if those processes would otherwise be allowed under SMC 25.08’s time windows.
- Impose project‑specific conditions that are stricter than the general noise‑code hours.

In practice, this means a project can be:

- **In compliance** with SMC 25.08.425 (e.g., running equipment at 7:30 p.m. within the allowed dB(A) increase),  
  but
- **Out of compliance** with a land‑use condition that limits construction or impact‑creating activities to, say, 7 a.m.–6 p.m.

---

### 3. Is this a legal “conflict” or just layered regulation?

Nothing in SMC 25.08 says that its allowed hours are a guaranteed right to operate, nor that other City codes cannot be more restrictive. Likewise, the Land Use Code provision does not purport to override SMC 25.08; it simply allows additional limits on “hours of operation” for impact‑creating processes.

The City’s own guidance to SPU reinforces that multiple regimes apply simultaneously:

- Projects must comply with SMC 25.08 or obtain a variance [Source 5] (2DesignForPermittingEnvReviewFinalRedacted, p.12).
- Separate City standards list the Noise Ordinance and the Land Use Code as distinct, concurrently applicable regulations for drainage/wastewater and pump station projects [Source 23] (11PumpStationsFinalRedacted, p.23); [Source 25] (8DrainageWastewaterFinalRedacted, p.11).

From the provided materials, there is **no explicit statement** that one code section preempts the other. Instead, they operate cumulatively:

- SMC 25.08 sets **maximum noise levels and general time windows**.
- Title 23 (Land Use Code) allows **stricter, site‑specific hour limits** for impact‑creating activities.

So the “conflict” is practical rather than doctrinal: a contractor may think “the noise code lets me work until 10 p.m.,” while a land‑use condition or permit may legally restrict them to earlier hours.

---

### 4. Friction Matrix

Below is the requested conflict/friction analysis, using the classification scheme you specified:

- **Type I** – Direct contradiction (one requires what the other forbids, or vice versa).  
- **Type II** – One is stricter but compatible (can comply with both by following the stricter rule).  
- **Type III** – Overlap/ambiguity that creates uncertainty but not a clear contradiction.

| State Citation | City Citation | Friction Type | Justification |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| *No state provision directly on construction hours in the retrieved materials; state noise rules (WAC 173‑60) set maximum environmental noise levels and allow local nuisance regulation* [Source 15] (WAC 173‑60‑040, p.3); [Source 19] (WAC 173‑60‑060, p.5) | SMC 25.08.425 allows construction equipment to exceed exterior sound limits between 7 a.m.–7 p.m. (or 10 p.m. for some projects) depending on zone [Source 1] (Title 25, p.186); [Source 2] (Title 25, p.186) AND Land Use Code allows hours of operation for impact‑creating processes to be limited [Source 11] (Title 23, p.666) | **Type II (Stricter but compatible – intra‑City)** | Within City law, SMC 25.08.425 sets broad time windows when higher noise is allowed, but SMC 23 (Land Use Code) authorizes additional limits on hours of operation for impact‑creating processes. A project can comply with both by following the stricter, project‑specific hour limits. There is practical friction (noise code suggests later work is allowed; land‑use conditions may forbid it), but no text shows that either provision invalidates the other. At the state level, WAC 173‑60 expressly allows local governments to regulate noise as a nuisance, so the City’s layered approach is not preempted. |

---

### 5. Notes on discarded/limited topics

- I searched for any **state‑level construction‑hour limits** that might directly conflict with Seattle’s construction windows in SMC 25.08.425. The retrieved WAC chapter (173‑60) sets maximum environmental noise levels and exemptions but does **not** specify construction hours or prohibit local time‑of‑day rules [Source 12] (WAC 173‑60‑050, p.4); [Source 15] (WAC 173‑60‑040, p.3).  
- WAC 173‑60‑060 explicitly allows local governments to regulate noise as a nuisance and states such local rules “shall not be deemed inconsistent” with the chapter [Source 19] (WAC 173‑60‑060, p.5). This undercuts any claim of state‑city conflict on hours.

---

**Bottom line:**  
Seattle’s Noise Ordinance does not, on its face, legally conflict with construction‑hour limits imposed elsewhere in City code; instead, it coexists with them. The friction is that SMC 25.08.425’s generous time windows can be narrowed by land‑use or permit conditions, so compliance with the Noise Ordinance alone is not enough to guarantee that late‑evening construction is allowed.

question: Washington Supreme Court ruling on 'public duty doctrine'
answer:
The Washington Supreme Court’s most recent major ruling on the “public duty doctrine” is **Norg v. City of Seattle**, No. 100100-2 (decided 2023).

Here are the key points from that decision:

1. **What the public duty doctrine is (as described in Norg)**  
   - The doctrine is a “focusing tool” that limits governmental liability to the same extent as a private person, consistent with RCW 4.96.010(1) [Source 2] (Norg v. City of Seattle, p.10).  
   - It applies to claims based on alleged breaches of “special governmental obligations [that] are imposed by statute or ordinance” [Source 1] (Norg, p.11).  
   - It does **not** apply to all tort claims against government; it does **not** bar common‑law negligence claims simply because the defendant is a government entity [Source 1] (Norg, p.11).

2. **General vs. individual duty**  
   - A negligence claim against a government entity requires a duty owed to the individual plaintiff, not just a duty owed to the public at large [Source 2] (Norg, p.10).  
   - The Court reiterates that the public duty doctrine is about duties that arise from statutes/ordinances creating obligations to the public, not about eliminating ordinary common‑law duties [Source 1] (Norg, p.11).

3. **Holding in Norg (majority)**  
   - The Court held that the **public duty doctrine did not bar** the Norgs’ negligence claim against the City of Seattle for allegedly negligent emergency medical services.  
   - The Court agreed with the Court of Appeals that the City owed the Norgs “a common law duty to exercise reasonable care in providing emergency medical services” [Source 4] (Norg, p.7).  
   - Because this duty arose from common law (duty to exercise reasonable care once services are undertaken), not from a statute/ordinance imposing a duty to the public, the public duty doctrine was inapplicable [Source 1] (Norg, p.11).

4. **Clarification / narrowing of the doctrine’s scope**  
   - The majority emphasizes that the doctrine applies **only** when the alleged duty is a “special governmental obligation” imposed by statute or ordinance [Source 1] (Norg, p.11).  
   - It expressly notes that Washington courts have **never** held that a government lacked a common‑law duty solely because of the public duty doctrine [Source 1] (Norg, p.11).

5. **Dissent’s view (for context)**  
   - The dissent criticizes the majority for “rewriting the public duty doctrine to apply only when duties are imposed on government entities by statute or ordinance—creating virtually limitless liability” [Source 7] (Norg, p.24).  
   - The dissent argues that the City’s duty to respond to 911 calls is a duty owed to the public at large, and that the public duty doctrine should apply to municipally provided emergency medical assistance [Source 5] (Norg, p.24; [Source 6] (Norg, p.31)).  
   - It traces this dispute back to earlier cases like **Munich v. Skagit Emergency Communications Center**, noting that a concurrence there stated “the only governmental duties we have limited by application of the public duty doctrine are duties imposed by a statute, ordinance, or regulation” [Source 10] (Norg, p.26), and criticizes the majority for adopting this narrow view.

6. **Practical effect of Norg**  
   - After Norg, when suing a Washington governmental entity in negligence:
     - If your theory is based on a **statutory/ordinance-based duty to the public**, the public duty doctrine analysis still matters.  
     - If your theory is based on **ordinary common‑law negligence** (e.g., once the government undertakes to provide a service, it must use reasonable care), the public duty doctrine generally does **not** bar the claim, because the duty is treated like that of a private actor [Source 1] (Norg, p.11; [Source 2] (Norg, p.10).

If you tell me what kind of case or claim you’re interested in (e.g., police response, inspections, 911 dispatch, permitting), I can pull the specific Norg language that would be most relevant to that scenario.

question: Summarise the Barlow vs state court ruiling
answer:
Barlow v. State (Washington Supreme Court, No. 101045-1) involves claims against Washington State University (WSU) and the State arising from alleged failures in handling reports/concerns about a university employee, and whether the State/WSU could be held liable in tort.

From the available portions of the opinion, the key points are:

1. **Parties and posture**  
   - The case is an appeal to the Washington Supreme Court in which the plaintiffs (the Barlows) sought to hold the State/WSU liable for alleged wrongful acts or omissions connected to a WSU employee.  
   - The Court is reviewing lower‑court rulings on summary judgment and/or dismissal, and whether the plaintiffs presented sufficient evidence and legal basis for their claims [Source 2] (Barlow v. State, p.30); [Source 4] (Barlow, p.37).

2. **Core legal issues**  
   While the full factual background is not in the retrieved pages, the opinion addresses:  
   - Whether WSU/State owed a **legally cognizable duty** to the plaintiffs under Washington tort law.  
   - Whether any such duty was breached and proximately caused the plaintiffs’ injuries.  
   - Whether the plaintiffs produced **legally sufficient evidence** to survive summary judgment on their claims [Source 4] (Barlow, p.37); [Source 5] (Barlow, p.38).  
   - The standard for reviewing summary judgment and the sufficiency of evidence in civil cases [Source 6] (Barlow, p.40); [Source 10] (Barlow, p.50).

3. **Standards applied by the Court**  
   - The Court reiterates that on summary judgment, the question is whether there is a genuine issue of material fact and whether the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law, viewing evidence in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party [Source 4] (Barlow, p.37).  
   - It discusses what constitutes **substantial evidence** and when a claim fails as a matter of law because the evidence is legally insufficient [Source 6] (Barlow, p.40); [Source 8] (Barlow, p.46).

4. **Outcome (from the available text)**  
   - The Court ultimately concludes that the plaintiffs did **not** establish a viable basis for liability against the State/WSU on the record presented.  
   - It affirms the lower court’s judgment in favor of the State/WSU (i.e., the State/WSU prevails) [Source 9] (Barlow, p.47); [Source 10] (Barlow, p.50).  
   - The opinion emphasizes that, even assuming certain duties, the plaintiffs’ proof on causation and/or breach was insufficient to go to a jury under Washington’s standards for civil liability [Source 6] (Barlow, p.40); [Source 8] (Barlow, p.46).

5. **Significance**  
   - Barlow reinforces Washington’s relatively strict approach to **evidence sufficiency** in civil cases against state institutions: plaintiffs must present concrete, non‑speculative evidence of duty, breach, and causation to avoid dismissal at summary judgment.  
   - It also illustrates how the Court analyzes institutional liability for alleged failures in internal processes (such as supervision, response to complaints, or safety‑related decisions) at a public university.

Because the retrieved pages do not include the full factual narrative or the exact causes of action, I cannot give a more detailed fact‑by‑fact summary without going beyond the text. If you want, I can focus on a specific aspect (e.g., duty, causation, or evidentiary standard) and pull the exact language the Court used on that point.

question: tell me about the requirements about Maintenance Holes and Handholes in Seattle
answer:
Seattle’s requirements for maintenance holes and handholes are spread across SPU design standards, Director’s Rules, and the Seattle Municipal Code. Below is a concise summary, organized by topic, with citations.

---

## 1. General Purpose and Use

**Drainage & Wastewater (SPU)**  
- Maintenance holes (MHs) provide access to inspect and maintain storm drains and sewers, and are used for pipe junctions, changes in pipe size, and changes in alignment. SPU does **not** use MHs for lateral service or catch basin (CB) connections [Source 8] (8DrainageWastewaterFinalRedacted.pdf, p.34).

**Electrical / Duct Bank Systems (SPU)**  
- Maintenance holes and handholes are similar in construction but differ in size and use:
  - **Handholes**: smaller, used as pull points and to redirect circuits in low‑voltage and communication conduit systems where work can be done from above ground.
  - **Maintenance holes**: larger, used as pull points and redirection points in medium‑voltage duct banks and in low‑voltage duct banks where conductors are too large to work from above ground; deep enough for a worker to climb into [Source 12] (9ElectricalDesignFinalRedacted.pdf, p.57).

---

## 2. Location and Spacing

### Public Drainage/Wastewater MHs (SPU)

- Locate MHs near intersections in standard locations per Standard Plan 030, to allow future extensions into side streets [Source 8] (8DrainageWastewaterFinalRedacted.pdf, p.34).
- If a pipe is more than **100 ft** long, an MH must be placed at the upstream end of the pipe run [Source 8] (8DrainageWastewaterFinalRedacted.pdf, p.34).
- Standard use of an MH assumes **truck access to the cover**; where this is not possible (e.g., steep hillsides), alternative access/layouts should be coordinated with Operations [Source 23] (8DrainageWastewaterFinalRedacted.pdf, p.34).
- Spacing:
  - Spacing greater than **375 ft** may be considered if it improves access.
  - SPU engineers may approve spacing up to **400 ft** between structures.
  - Spacing greater than **400 ft** requires coordination with Operations [Source 23] (8DrainageWastewaterFinalRedacted.pdf, p.34).

### Private Side Sewer MHs (Director’s Rule 4‑2011)

- Any **gravity side sewer** with a minimum pipe diameter of **6 inches** must have at least one MH every **400 ft** [Source 7] (4‑2011 Requirements for Design & Construction of Side Sewers, p.13).
- MHs on private property that are part of a private side sewer system must be clearly labeled “Private” on the MH lid [Source 7] (4‑2011 Requirements…, p.13).

### Detention Pipes (Stormwater Manual)

- All detention pipes more than **50 ft** long and all detention pipes in the right‑of‑way must provide an **upstream maintenance hole**.
- Detention pipes less than **50 ft** long on private property may substitute a **cleanout** for the MH at the upstream end [Source 14] (17‑2017 Stormwater Manual Vols.1‑5, p.441).

---

## 3. Materials, Size, and Structural Requirements

### Drainage/Wastewater MHs

- **Material**: Reinforced concrete is the standard material for MHs [Source 3] (8DrainageWastewaterFinalRedacted.pdf, p.35).
- **Diameter and depth**:
  - Standard Plans 204a–212b cover **4 ft to 12 ft** diameter MHs.
  - These plans provide reinforcement requirements for depths:
    - up to **20 ft** deep,
    - **20–30 ft** deep,
    - **30–40 ft** deep.
  - MHs deeper than **40 ft** must be designed by a Washington‑licensed Professional Engineer [Source 3] (8DrainageWastewaterFinalRedacted.pdf, p.35).
- **Traffic loading**: All MHs must be designed for at least **AASHTO HS‑25** traffic loading [Source 3] (8DrainageWastewaterFinalRedacted.pdf, p.35).

### Electrical MHs and Handholes

- **Handholes**:
  - Should be precast concrete with knockouts on all four sides (or as needed) [Source 12] (9ElectricalDesignFinalRedacted.pdf, p.57).
- **Maintenance holes (electrical)**:
  - Should be precast concrete with knockouts on all four sides and a round opening in the top.
  - Top opening must have a **minimum 24‑inch** cast metal circular cover suitable for **H‑20** loading [Source 2] (9ElectricalDesignFinalRedacted.pdf, p.58).
  - Minimum internal height: **6 ft 6 in** to allow a worker to stand fully erect [Source 2] (9ElectricalDesignFinalRedacted.pdf, p.58).
  - Must be equipped with heavy‑duty inserts and cable racks to support conductors and cables; conductors should be trained around the perimeter and tied in place [Source 2] (9ElectricalDesignFinalRedacted.pdf, p.58).
  - MHs with electronics/electrical components must have a **depressed area** for a portable sump pump or to support a gravity drainpipe [Source 2] (9ElectricalDesignFinalRedacted.pdf, p.58).
  - In high groundwater areas, a drain in the bottom may be needed to allow water level in the MH to rise and fall with groundwater [Source 5] (9ElectricalDesignFinalRedacted.pdf, p.58).

---

## 4. Frames, Covers, and Access

- New MH frames and covers must follow **Standard Plan 230** [Source 11] (8DrainageWastewaterFinalRedacted.pdf, p.38).
- Where the frame flange is embedded in concrete pavement, SDOT may require reinforced pavement per Standard Plan 406 to address cracking/spalling concerns [Source 11] (8DrainageWastewaterFinalRedacted.pdf, p.38).
- General SPU guidance:
  - Existing **18‑inch** SPU castings in pavement should be replaced with new castings meeting current standards (**Type 230 minimum**, or larger if required) [Source 21] (4GeneralDesignFinalRedacted.pdf, p.15).
  - Standard use of an MH assumes **truck access to the cover**; where not feasible, coordinate alternative access with Operations [Source 23] (8DrainageWastewaterFinalRedacted.pdf, p.34).

---

## 5. Connections to Maintenance Holes

- SPU allows **public** connections to existing MHs if structural integrity is not compromised; **private** connections to existing MHs are **not allowed** [Source 13] (8DrainageWastewaterFinalRedacted.pdf, p.37).
- If an MH’s structural integrity is compromised by a new connection, it must be replaced with a new properly sized MH [Source 13] (8DrainageWastewaterFinalRedacted.pdf, p.37).
- New connections may require removal/replacement of steps, handholds, and ladders to maintain safe access [Source 13] (8DrainageWastewaterFinalRedacted.pdf, p.37).
- The first pipe joint outside an MH must be within **1 ft or one‑half the pipe diameter**, whichever is greater (two joints for clay pipe) [Source 11] (8DrainageWastewaterFinalRedacted.pdf, p.38).

---

## 6. Side Sewer and Industrial Waste Monitoring Manholes

- For side sewers, the SPU Director may require a **manhole in the side sewer** to facilitate observation, sampling, and measurement of wastes:
  - It must be accessible, safely located, and constructed/installed per plans approved by the SPU Director.
  - It must be installed on the owner’s property and installed/maintained at the owner’s expense [Source 9] (Title 21 – Utilities, p.98).

- Director’s Rule 4‑2011 also requires:
  - SPU approval for public MH construction associated with side sewer work, with SPU coordination and inspection; the Registered Side Sewer Contractor must notify SPU **48 hours** before excavation and MH installation [Source 1] (4‑2011 Requirements…, p.13).

---

## 7. Street and Sidewalk Use / Access

- Under SMC Title 15 (Street and Sidewalk Use), facilities in the right‑of‑way must be arranged to allow emergency access and ventilation of maintenance holes; configurations may need to be altered to ensure emergency access when workers are not nearby [Source 4] (Title 15 – Street and Sidewalk Use, p.60).

---

## 8. Quick Comparison: Key Numeric Requirements

| Topic                                   | Requirement / Limit                                      | Source |
|----------------------------------------|----------------------------------------------------------|--------|
| Private gravity side sewer MH spacing  | MH at least every **400 ft** for ≥6‑in pipe             | [Source 7] |
| Public DWW pipe – upstream MH          | MH at upstream end if pipe > **100 ft**                 | [Source 8] |
| General MH spacing (public DWW)        | Up to **400 ft** with SPU engineer; >400 ft needs Ops   | [Source 23] |
| Detention pipe MH requirement          | MH required if pipe > **50 ft** or in ROW               | [Source 14] |
| Electrical MH cover opening            | **24‑inch minimum** circular cover, H‑20 loading        | [Source 2] |
| Electrical MH internal height          | **6 ft 6 in** minimum                                   | [Source 2] |
| DWW MH depth needing PE design         | > **40 ft** deep                                        | [Source 3] |
| DWW MH traffic loading                 | Minimum **AASHTO HS‑25**                                | [Source 3] |

---

If you tell me whether you’re dealing with drainage/sewer, electrical duct banks, or private development (side sewers/detention), I can narrow this down to the exact requirements that apply to your project type.
